metadata.title: Bell OH-58 Kiowa
aws::graph::propositions: Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP) and OH-58D Development
The Army initiated the Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP).
The Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP) resulted from the Army's decision to acquire the NTSH.
NTSH stands for New Training Scout Helicopter.
Bell Helicopter redesigned their scout aircraft to compete for the AHIP contract.
Hughes Helicopters redesigned their scout aircraft to compete for the AHIP contract.
Bell Helicopter offered the Model 406 for the AHIP contract.
The Model 406 was a more robust version of the OH-58.
Hughes Helicopters offered an upgraded version of the OH-6 for the AHIP contract.
Bell Helicopter Textron was awarded a development contract on 21 September 1981.
The first prototype of the Bell Model 406 performed its maiden flight on 6 October 1983.
The Bell Model 406 entered service as the OH-58D.
The OH-58D entered service two years after the first prototype's maiden flight.
The OH-58D was initially intended for attack roles.
The OH-58D was initially intended for cavalry roles.
The OH-58D was initially intended for artillery roles.
The Army only approved a low initial production level for the OH-58D.
The Army confined the OH-58D's role to field artillery observation.
The Army directed that a follow-on test be conducted to further evaluate the OH-58D.
The follow-on test was directed due to perceived deficiencies in the OH-58D.

text:
### Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP)
The Army's decision to acquire the NTSH resulted in the "Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP)". Both Bell Helicopter and Hughes Helicopters redesigned their scout aircraft to compete for the contract. Bell offered a more robust version of the OH-58 in their Model 406, and Hughes offered an upgraded version of the OH-6. On 21 September 1981, Bell Helicopter Textron was awarded a development contract. On 6 October 1983, the first prototype performed its maiden flight, and the aircraft entered service two years later as the OH-58D.
Initially intended for attack, cavalry, and artillery roles, the Army only approved a low initial production level and confined the OH-58D's role to field artillery observation. The Army also directed that a follow-on test be conducted to further evaluate it due to perceived deficiencies.
